title: DS310.12 Query vs. Search | DataStax Enterprise 6 Search
description:
#DataStaxAcademy #DS310
DS310.12 Query vs. Search
In this unit we take a in-depth look at the difference between a query and a search, and how DSE Search can do both.

LEARN FOR FREE at https://academy.datastax.com -- access all the FREE complete courses, tutorials, and hands-on exercises.

ASK QUESTIONS at https://community.datastax.com -- where experts from DataStax & the Apache Cassandra community share their expertise everyday.

transcript.text: [Music] now let's take a step back and analyze what the difference between a query and a search really means a query is going to return only the results that match the value provided performance is going to be optimal since you're querying on the partition key and that acts as a lookup in cql querying different columns may need multiple tables and data duplication an example is as we see here retrieving the information for a movie with a specific id the disadvantages of these queries are going to be you have to use the full text value for your lookup and of course all queries are going to be limited by your primary key definitions now with search we typically do not need to retrieve all the results and we typically don't even know what we're looking for in these cases only the most relevant results are the ones we're interested in and we rarely go beyond the first end results where n is typically 10. relevancy means each row is given a score based on how well it matches the search parameters and the default ordering is going to be based on those scores this is certainly much more flexible as exact values aren't required generally this won't be as fast as a query but we still consider this near real time as the results are typically given sub second let's look at the same examples using different functionality because we are leveraging search a cql search request is a cql query that includes the solar underscore query column in the where clause where this column value is a string containing the leucine search expression most but not all sql predicates are still valid in the search request selecting columns the where predicate limiting the number of rows all that's supported what isn't supported are dml statements statements such as inserting updating and deleting
